awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  EDGES-3: Validating and Refining Global 21cm Measurements of Cosmic Dawn
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers are searching for signs of the first stars and galaxies that formed in the universe.  This period in cosmic history is called the Epoch of Reionization (EoR). The Experiment to Detect the Global EoR Signature (EDGES) is an ongoing project to study this early period. In 2018, EDGES reported the first-ever detection of evidence of light from the first stars. These stars where shining 180 million years after the Big Bang, when the universe was merely one percent of its current age. The EDGES project uses radio observations to probe the early universe. This project will build a new radio antenna and receiver for EDGES. The instrument will be used to confirm previously reported evidence. Students from the diverse community of Arizona State University will help to build the instrument and analyze its data. This experience will help to prepare them for future careers and give them a unique research opportunity.

Observing the formation of the first stars, galaxies, and black holes over 13.5 billion years ago is the next frontier in observational cosmology. After the first stars formed, they produced a background of ultra-violet photons that affected the surrounding hydrogen gas, enabling the gas to be detected in absorption against the cosmic microwave background. In early 2018 this research team reported the first evidence for detection of this signal, but the amplitude was twice the predicted level and the timing of the signal was earlier than expected. This project will develop a new radio antenna and receiver that will improve on previous performance by a factor of three, enabling a verification of the previous detection and detailed characterization of the signal. The project will engage students from Arizona State University to build the instrument and analyze its data, preparing them for future careers. The research team will disseminate technical advances in radio instrumentation through technical memos and journal articles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main goals of astrophysics is to understand the history of the universe. The least understood period is when the first stars and galaxies formed over 13 billion years ago. Radio observations at the same wavelengths used for FM radio and TV broadcasts are expected to provide a unique new view of the early universe. Radio telescopes can detect the hydrogen gas between early galaxies, which is influenced by ultraviolet and X-ray light from the stars in those galaxies.

This award supported the Experiment to Detect the Global EoR Signature (EDGES). The experiment aims to develop instruments capable of high-precision observations of the radio spectrum to study the hydrogen gas in the early universe. We conducted both scientific and technical investigations, examining factors that can limit instrument performance, such as the properties of radio antennas, numerical models used to characterize them, laboratory calibration methods, and data analysis techniques. We also characterized external sources of error, including Earth's ionosphere and astronomical radio emissions from our Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies. The main findings of the project are documented in two public collections of memoranda and journal articles.

Based on these studies, we constructed the EDGES-3 instrument. This instrument features a hollow antenna with a radio receiver installed inside. It is unique because it includes additional calibration equipment within the antenna, improving performance over earlier instruments. We deployed the instrument to Devon Island in Canada for a temporary observing campaign and then to Western Australia. In Australia, we built a large metal wire mesh under the instrument to reduce the effects of soil moisture and rocks below the antenna, further enhancing its performance. We acquired observations over 700 days.

We developed new software tools to analyze data from the experiment. These tools improve on older versions by making it easier to track data manipulation. They are open source and publicly available for other scientists. We also added tools to fit models of the expected signals to observations using Bayesian inference statistical techniques. Using these tools, we investigated data quality and determined the best configuration of models we use in our instrument calibration.

Older EDGES instruments found evidence of a signal from hydrogen gas that was unexpectedly large. We used observations from the new instrument to test for this signal again. To reduce confirmation bias, we made processing choices before analyzing the full dataset. The final results from this analysis are part of a Ph.D. dissertation that will be completed and published soon.

We collaborated with other NSF-supported research projects, including the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA) team, to investigate calibration techniques beneficial to both projects. We also worked with others to develop new models of the astronomical sky for our data analysis and created new statistical techniques to help select the best models.

This award directly supported the research and training of two undergraduate students, one Ph.D. student, and one early-career research engineer. Additionally, four more undergraduates, one more Ph.D. student, and two early-career scientists conducted research based on the project.
